qas.question: Who required no restrictions regarding God's power?
When did Buridan state that teams of ten horses could not open a bellow with a sealed port?
the 1277 Paris Condemnations led to what conclusion?

answers.text: God could create a vacuum if he so wished.

qas.question: What was a common belief about vacuums and nature?
what was the belief that nature abhorred a vaccuum called?
What did Bishop Etienne Tempier believe prevented a vacuum from forming?
What was the commonly held view in the medieval period that God could not create a vacuum called?

plausible_answers.text: God could create a vacuum if he so wished

qas.question: What point of view regarding God became popular in the 14th century?
According to Walter Burley in the 14th century, what could teams of ten horses not pull open?
What did Walter Burley require there be no restrictions on in the 14th century?

context: Medieval thought experiments into the idea of a vacuum considered whether a vacuum was present, if only for an instant, between two flat plates when they were rapidly separated. There was much discussion of whether the air moved in quickly enough as the plates were separated, or, as Walter Burley postulated, whether a <b5_0>'celestial agent'<b5_0/> prevented the vacuum arising. The commonly held view that <a3_0>nature abhorred a vacuum<a3_0/> was called <a4_0><b6_0>horror vacui<b6_0/><a4_0/>. Speculation that even God could not create a vacuum if he wanted to was shut down[clarification needed] by the 1277 Paris condemnations of <a0_0>Bishop Etienne Tempier<a0_0/>, which required there to be no restrictions on <b9_0>the powers of God<b9_0/>, which led to the conclusion that <a2_0><b7_0>God could create a vacuum if he so wished<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> Jean Buridan reported in the <a1_0>14th century<a1_0/> that teams of ten horses could not pull open <b8_0>bellows<b8_0/> when the port was sealed.
